Dear Roseburg students and families,

You did it! Together, we made it through this difficult spring, facing challenges none of us ever expected and growing in ways we never thought possible. We are so very proud of all of our students and families.

We know there were bumps along the way, frustrations and sad moments, but we believe that we are entering summer with the confidence that we can achieve anything when we work together.

We know this because, over the past few months, we saw our teachers and staff do everything possible to maintain relationships with their students and to continue the education process. We know this because of the love and support our community showed to our graduating seniors. And we know this because we all worked together to keep ourselves and one another healthy and safe.

We hope that you have a wonderful summer break. You deserve it! #TogetherWeLearn

District to add dinner to “grab and go” meals

On Monday, Roseburg Public Schools will add dinner items to all “grab and go” meals currently being served via bus routes and at school sites.

Those accepting meals will now receive a breakfast component with fruit and milk; a lunch component with fruit or vegetables and milk; and a ready-to-heat dinner component with fruit or a vegetable. Each bag will come with instructions on how to heat the dinner portion.

The meals are available for all youth ages 0-18. Adults may visit the bus stops or school sites and pick up a bag with meals for their children without their child being present. Children at bus stops may also take an extra meal for other youth in the home.

Students and families can find school site and bus delivery schedules and information on our website at www.roseburg.k12.or.us/community/covid-19/meals-for-students.

Roseburg Public Schools is seeking feedback from parents and caregivers.

We believe students are more successful in school when their parents and caregivers work collaboratively with and are supported by teachers and administrators. Because this relationship is so important, we need to learn more about what we are doing well and how we can improve our support for parents.

For the second year, the Institute for Research & Reform in Education (iRRE) will be assisting us with collecting your feedback through the Roseburg Parent Survey. The survey email is going out today to all parents and caregivers with valid emails on file at your child’s school. The survey window will be open until March 19.

The survey should take approximately 5 to 8 minutes. Parents may complete a survey for each school attended by a member of their family. All responses are confidential.

We thank you for your help in guiding our school district as we strive to support every student in partnership with every parent and caregiver.

For more information or questions, please call the District Office at 541-440-4014.

post_text: It’s the time of year to stuff stockings full of goodies and hang them by the chimney with care, but Melrose Elementary School students have spent the past few weeks putting their own spin on the tradition. Students kicked off a sock drive before Thanksgiving and were able to collect close to 700 pairs of socks with the support of community organizations and local residents. The children carefully filled socks with toothbrushes, toothpaste, candy, Chapstick, handwarmers and other comfort items – also donated – before tying them closed with ribbon and handwriting gift tags. The socks and goodies have been donated to Umpqua Valley Nursing and Rehab, Rose Haven Nursing Center, veterans in need through the VA and to organizations that serve people who are homeless. Melrose Principal Tammy Rasmussen said the sock drive is part of the school’s “sharing and caring month.” The project allowed students who expressed concern for those in need over the holidays to turn their worries into action. Melrose thanks everyone in the community who helped make this project possible.

We have partnered with Douglas Education Service District to bring a special, inclusive classroom that has never been seen before for Roseburg Public Schools preschoolers.

The classroom, which will be located at Eastwood Elementary School, is designed for preschool students (4 to 5 years old) who experience social-emotional developmental delays. It’s designed to help the students prepare for kindergarten through the use of high-quality SEL curriculum, small group intervention and parent education. Examples of social-emotional developmental delays include anxiety, ADHD and students who come from traumatic backgrounds.

A huge thanks to The Ford Family Foundation for making this possible!

Friday, Nov. 15, will be Middle School Night, which means that while everyone is welcome, any middle school student can show their school ID and get a free ticket to that night's performance. (At least one paying adult per four students.) Immediately after the performance that night, the cast and crew will have a Q&A session with the middle school students. This is a great opportunity for middle schoolers to see live theater and get the inside scoop of what it's really like backstage and how the show works!

Last night at their Back to School night, Fremont Middle School celebrated their Blue Zones Project approval! Around 400 students and parents were there to celebrate the first Middle School to become Blue Zones Project Approved. Fremont has led the way in our community by including Blue Zones Project ideals in their Natural Resources’ class where they are planting and maintaining a school garden put in by UC-VEG's Kitchen Garden Project! Fremont is also piloting Restorative Justice for the secondary schools in Roseburg leading theway with promoting a strong community feeling among their Fremont family! Great work Fremont Generals!

post_text: Superintendent Lee Paterson was presented with the coveted Crystal Apple Award at the June 12 Board meeting, in honor of his dogged determination to bring awareness about each person’s need for “Belonging, Influence and Adequacy.” Superintendent Paterson has steadfastly advocated that most difficulties may be avoided or resolved simply by assuring that we acknowledge the very human need for these three things. Roseburg Public Schools will make every effort to carry forward this noble endeavor, and thanks Paterson for his leadership, insight and compassion as he accepted the Board’s challenge of assuming leadership of the District this year.

In order to ensure the safety of students, staff and community members, Roseburg Public Schools plans to thin several trees on the Fir Grove Elementary campus that have become a hazard.
About six of the fir trees on campus have begun to show signs of wasting, and several more were damaged in last month’s snowstorm. The district has taped off the areas around the trees to block access. The sidewalk that is used as an approach to the school from Harvard Avenue is not in the area of concern so it will continue to be accessible. The play areas under the trees will be closed until the hazards are removed.
Professional tree service operators will be employed in the near future to remove the wasting trees and to prune hazard branches and weak tops on other trees as needed.
Superintendent Lee Paterson said our goal is to make the little stand of trees we call Fir Grove safer and healthier, so that children can continue to enjoy the little forest as generations before them have, for a long time into the future.

February 20th was the 100th day of school! One hundred days of learning how to count to 100! One hundred days of learning to read! One hundred days of being with your friends at recess! One hundred glorious days in a Roseburg Public Schools kindergarten class! What better way to celebrate than coming to school as a 100-year-old kindergartener?!

Green Elementary School kindergarten students did just that. They came to school as a centenarian for the day. The 5-year-olds dressed the part, some sporting gray hair and glasses to canes and hair rollers.

The day is dedicated to the number 100. Counting to 100 by 1’s, 5’s, and maybe even 10’s. Celebrating 100 days of school because school is 100 percent on the list of every 5-year-old’s most fun things to do on their way to 100 years old!

post_text: Some of the biggest supporters of the new Roseburg Public Library were students in the Melrose Elementary 4th and 5th-grade reading group. They wrote letters last spring to City Manager Lance Colley and Douglas Education Service District Superintendent Michael Lasher in support of opening the library. On the day of the grand opening, they received a private tour and a sneak peek at the new Children's Room. They also presented Lasher, Colley and Library Director Kris Wiley with thank-you letters and helped with a little cleaning to prepare the space for the grand opening celebration. We're so proud of these students and their dedication to making their community a better place!

The Fir Grove Elementary Fourth- and Fifth-Grade Choir brought holiday cheer to Linus Oakes Retirement Center this week with specially prepared holiday music.
This choir is made up of students who volunteer their free time after school to hone their musical skills. The Fir Grove Choir is directed by Harmony Klingenmeyer and is over 30 students strong. Community service is part of Mrs. Klingenmeyer’s educational philosophy. She has been instilling in her students the power of music to help heal themselves and others.
“I believe the older generations have important things to impart to children and that the presence of children can be a blessing to the elderly,” Mrs. Klingenmeyer said. “I hope this activity encourages community connections between old and young.”

Joseph Lane Middle School students will receive a visit on Friday, May 12, from former NFL player Joey Harrington, who is joining them for a field day and to deliver $6,000 to support health and wellness efforts. He will be on campus from 9 a.m. to noon.

JoLane is one of five winning schools in a nationwide contest co-sponsored by Dannon Danimals, a children’s yogurt brand, and Fuel Up to Play 60, an in-school wellness program. Each winning school is receiving $6,000 from Dannon and a visit from a former NFL player. The visits will take the form of field days consisting of fun physical activities and drills from all students, along with nutrition information and Dannon samples.

Harrington, a Portland native, played college football at the University of Oregon before being drafted third overall in 2002 by the Detroit Lions. During his NFL career, he passed for over 14,000 yards and tallied 79 touchdowns over the course of six seasons.

Here's to a great opportunity for our students!

Congratulations Roseburg High School!

post_text:
Congratulations to students Malia Narciso (Green), Peter Blackketter (Hucrest) and Brayden Michael (Joseph Lane), who were selected by their schools and recognized as outstanding students at the Wednesday (April 26) board meeting. Green Elementary librarian Pattie Adams received a Crystal Apple Award in honor of her ability to build strong staff and student relationships. Get more quick snippets of the board meeting in the Board Clips summary.
Board agendas, past board clips and full meeting minutes can be found on our website: http://www.roseburg.k12.or.us/depts/board/boardmtgs.html.

post_text: It's open enrollment time in our district! Open enrollment applications are now being accepted at all schools in the Roseburg Public Schools district. Requests from students living outside the district wishing to attend a Roseburg school, as well as those living within the district wishing to change schools, are welcome now for the 2016-17 school year. Decisions on placements for all transfer requests will be made the third Friday in May (May 19), so get the request form filled out soon. Call 541-440-4015 or visit www.roseburg.k12.or.us for more information. Roseburg Public Schools: Great kids, great teachers, great schools!
